bioghist.p: Eldridge R. F. Johnson was a pioneer in the development of underwater photography. He was also an explorer, yachtsman, and researcher. He was vice president of Victor Talking Machine Co. until the business was sold to RCA in 1927, at which time he resigned and organized a small research and development firm. During World War II, he enlisted in Naval Research, where he was involved with underwater demolition and underwater photography. After the war, he reorganized his company as Fenjohn Underwater Equipment Co. (in Ardmore, Pennsylvania). He patented several inventions and published scientific papers on the absorption and scattering of light by water, and on the preservation of film. He served on the board of trustees of the Academy of Natural Sciences. He was the principal sponsor of University of Pennsylvania expeditions up the Paraguay River and into the Matto Grosso in Brazil, and participated in a number of other expeditions to Africa, Asia, the Bahamas, and Andros Island.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of photographs, negatives, and lantern slides, and 16 mm films taken by E.R. Fenimore Johnson between 1929 and 1975. Subjects include diving and underwater photography equipment, ships and harbors, landscapes, trees and plants, fishes, animals, birds, and native peoples of Brazil and Africa, and personal photos of Johnson, his family, friends, and colleagues. The bulk of the photos are present either as negatives and contact prints or as prints mounted on cards with labels. The collection also includes six oversized albums of prints and a set of loose prints from the Matto Grosso Expedition, 1929.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
